Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative Research: Fossil Insect Collaborative: A Deep-Time Approach to Studying Diversification and Response to Environmental Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fossil insects provide a unique deep-time record of ecological and evolutionary response to past environmental changes and therefore are invaluable for understanding the impacts of climate change on the current biodiversity crisis. Given current models of future climate change and the important role that insects play in human society (biodiversity, pests, pollination, vectors of disease) the ability to access these data and make predictions about future insect populations becomes even more urgent. The Fossil Insect Collaborative will make available all the major collections of fossil insect specimens in the United States by creating electronic specimen records consisting of digital images and associated collection data.

The digitized fossil insect collections will be made broadly accessible to the research community, K-16 education, government and industry, the general public, and the media through the project website and a central site integrating all the paleobiological Thematic Collections Networks called iDigPaleo. Mobile apps and activities that allow a wide variety of users to experience and interact directly with the collections data will be developed. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project resulted in the following outcomes:

  • Establishment of a dedicated digitization lab at PRI Center for Paleontology with infrastructure to digitize fossils using both photomicrographic and photomacrographic equipment. The digitization suite comprises a number of computer workstations, a state-of-the-art motorized zoom stereomicroscope with dedicated computer control, and a stand-alone macrophotography system comprising a high-end digital SLR, focus stacking rail, multiple macro lenses, copy stand and dedicated computer control.
  • Creation of a new online database using Specify 7 software. The database is hosted by the Prairie Research Institute at the University of Illinois Urbana Champaign.
  • Databazing of >2,000 fossil insect specimens.
  • High resolution imaging of >2,000 fossil insect specimens.
  • Training of three undergraduate students throughout the lifetime of the project.

In addition to the abovementioned outcomes, the project also resulted in the following publications:

Published:

  • Robinson, J.L., Thomas, M.J. & Heads, S.W. 2018. A fossil caddisfly (Insecta, Trichoptera) from the Eocene of Colorado. Zootaxa 4403: 389–394.
  • Makarkin, V.N., Wedmann, S. & Heads, S.W. 2018. A systematic reappraisal of Araripeneuridae (Neuroptera: Myrmeleontoidea), with description of new species from the Lower Cretaceous Crato Formation of Brazil. Cretaceous Research 84: 600–621.
  • Heads, S.W., Miller, A.N., Crane, J.L., Thomas, M.J., Ruffatto, D.M., Methven, A.S., Raudabaugh, D.B. & Wang, Y. 2017. The oldest fossil mushroom. PLoS ONE 12(6): e0178327, 1–6.
  • Makarkin, V.N., Heads, S.W. & Wedmann, S. 2017. Taxonomic study of the Cretaceous lacewing family Babinskaiidae (Neuroptera: Myrmeleontoidea: Nymphidoidae), with description of new taxa. Cretaceous Research 78: 149–160.
  • Heads, S.W., Thomas, M.J. & Wang, Y. 2014. A remarkable new pygmy grasshopper (Orthoptera, Tetrigidae) in Miocene amber from the Dominican Republic. ZooKeys 429: 87–100.

In addition to published papers, there are three additional papers currently in preparation that are a direct result of the project:

  • Heads, S.W. et al. (in prep) The earliest fossil cicada (Insects: Hemiptera) from the Lower Cretaceous Crato Formation of Brazil. Being prepared for Zootaxa.
  • Heads, S.W. et al. (in prep) A new species of the beetle-like roachoid Ponopterix (Insecta: Blattodea) from the Lower Cretaceous Crato Formation of Brazil. Being prepared for Palaeodiversity.
  • Heads, S.W. et al. (in prep) The oldest fossil Tetrigidae (Insecta: Orthoptera) from the Triassic Cow Branch Formation of Virginia, USA. Being prepared for Journal of Paleontology.
